message_1: A medical researcher is testing a new drug intended to lower blood pressure. The average systolic blood pressure for a population of patients with high blood pressure is known to be 148 mmHg. The researcher selects a sample of 30 patients and administers the new drug to them. After a month of treatment, the researcher measures the systolic blood pressure of each patient in the sample and finds that the average is 142 mmHg with a standard deviation of 6 mmHg. Can the researcher conclude at 5% level of significance that the new drug is effective in lowering blood pressure? Use hypothesis testing to answer the question.
message_2:
To determine if the new drug is effective in lowering blood pressure, we will perform a hypothesis test using the following steps:

Step 1: State the null hypothesis (H0) and alternative hypothesis (H1)
H0: The new drug has no effect on blood pressure (µ = 148 mmHg)
H1: The new drug lowers blood pressure (µ < 148 mmHg)

Step 2: Determine the level of significance (α)
α = 0.05

Step 3: Calculate the test statistic
We will use the t-test statistic since the sample size is small (n = 30) and the population standard deviation is unknown. The formula for the t-test statistic is:

t = (sample mean - population mean) / (sample standard deviation / √n)

t = (142 - 148) / (6 / √30)
t = -6 / (6 / √30)
t = -6 / (6 / 5.48)
t = -6 / 1.095
t ≈ -5.48

Step 4: Determine the critical value
Since this is a one-tailed test (we are only interested in whether the new drug lowers blood pressure), we will look up the critical value for a t-distribution with 29 degrees of freedom (n - 1) and α = 0.05.

Using a t-table or calculator, the critical value is approximately -1.699.

Step 5: Compare the test statistic to the critical value
Our test statistic, t ≈ -5.48, is more extreme (further to the left) than the critical value, -1.699.

Step 6: Make a decision
Since the test statistic is more extreme than the critical value, we reject the null hypothesis (H0) in favor of the alternative hypothesis (H1). We can conclude at a 5% level of significance that the new drug is effective in lowering blood pressure.
